children.value: Widely considered the gold standard for
values by fitting the signal recovery curve acquired at different delays after an inversion pulse (180°). In a typical
at thermal equilibrium is inverted using a 180°
), a 90° excitation pulse is applied, followed by a readout imaging sequence (typically a
readout) to create a snapshot of the longitudinal
map was acquired using a saturation-recovery technique (90° as a preparation pulse instead of 180°) by
. Some distinct advantages of inversion recovery are its large dynamic range of signal change and an insensitivity to pulse sequence parameter imperfections
. Despite its proven robustness at measuring
, inversion recovery is scarcely used in practice, because conventional implementations require repetition times (
s) on the order of 2 to 5
, making it challenging to acquire whole-organ
maps in a clinically feasible time. Nonetheless, it is continuously used as a reference measurement during the development of new techniques, or when comparing different
mapping techniques, and several variations of the
technique have been developed, making it practical for some applications

startup
clear all

%% Setup parameters
% All times are in seconds
% All flip angles are in degrees

params.TR = 5.0;
params.TI = linspace(0.001, params.TR, 1000);
            
params.TE = 0.004;
params.T2 = 0.040;
            
params.EXC_FA = 90;  % Excitation flip angle
params.INV_FA = 180; % Inversion flip angle

params.signalConstant = 1;

%% Calculate signals
%
% The option 'GRE-IR' selects the analytical equations for the
% gradient echo readout inversion recovery experiment The option
% '4' is a flag that selects the long TR approximation of the 
% analytical solution (TR>>T1), Eq. 3 of the blog post.
%
% To see all the options available, run:
% `help inversion_recovery.analytical_solution`

% White matter
params.T1 = 0.900; % in seconds

signal_WM = inversion_recovery.analytical_solution(params, 'GRE-IR', 4);

% Grey matter
params.T1 = 1.500;  % in seconds
signal_GM = inversion_recovery.analytical_solution(params, 'GRE-IR', 4);

% CSF
params.T1 = 4.000;  % in seconds
signal_CSF = inversion_recovery.analytical_solution(params, 'GRE-IR', 4);

startup
clear all

%% Setup parameters
% All times are in seconds
% All flip angles are in degrees

params.TR = 5.0;
params.TI = linspace(0.001, params.TR, 1000);
            
params.TE = 0.004;
params.T2 = 0.040;
            
params.EXC_FA = 90;  % Excitation flip angle
params.INV_FA = 180; % Inversion flip angle

params.signalConstant = 1;

T1_range = 0.25:0.25:5; % in seconds

%% Calculate signals
%
% The option 'GRE-IR' selects the analytical equations for the
% gradient echo readout inversion recovery experiment. The option
% '1' is a flag that selects full analytical solution equation 
% (no approximation), Eq. 1 of the blog post. The option '4' is a
% flag that selects the long TR approximation of the analytical 
% solution (TR>>T1), Eq. 3 of the blog post.
%
% To see all the options available, run:
% `help inversion_recovery.analytical_solution`

for ii = 1:length(T1_range)
    params.T1 = T1_range(ii);
    
    signal_T1_Eq1{ii} = inversion_recovery.analytical_solution(params, 'GRE-IR', 1);

    signal_T1_Eq3{ii} = inversion_recovery.analytical_solution(params, 'GRE-IR', 4);
end

noise creating a non-zero level at the signal null. If phase data is also available, then a phase term must be added to the fitting equation

– without a precision penalty – by using a reduced-dimension
) algorithm. It was demonstrated that the following simplified 5-parameter equation can be sufficient for accurate

Despite a widely acknowledged robustness for measuring accurate

). It takes about to 10-25 minutes to acquire a single-slice

(2-5 s) and conventional cartesian gradient readout imaging acquires one phase encode line per excitation (for a total of ~100-200 phase encode lines). The long acquisition time makes it challenging to acquire whole-organ
maps in clinically feasible protocol times. Nonetheless, it is useful as a reference measurement for comparisons against other
mapping methods, or to acquire a single-slice
map of a tissue to get
estimates for optimization of other pulse sequences.

s, and that the transverse magnetization is perfectly spoiled at the end of each
. Bloch simulations – a numerical approach at solving the
for a set of spins at each time point –  provide a more realistic estimate of the signal if the number of repetition times is small (i.e. a steady-state is not achieved). As can be seen from
, the number of repetitions required to reach a steady state not only depends on
, but also on the flip angle; flip angles near the Ernst angle need more
s to reach a steady state. Preparation pulses or an outward-in
acquisition pattern are typically sufficient to reach a steady state by the time that the center of
is acquired, which is where most of the image contrast resides.

startup
clear all

%% Setup parameters
% All times are in milliseconds
% All flip angles are in degrees

TR_range = 5:5:200;

params.EXC_FA = 1:90;

%% Calculate signals
%
% To see all the options available, run `help vfa_t1.analytical_solution`

for ii = 1:length(TR_range)
    params.TR = TR_range(ii);
    
    % White matter
    params.T1 = 900; % in milliseconds

    signal_WM(ii,:) = vfa_t1.analytical_solution(params);

    % Grey matter
    params.T1 = 1500;  % in milliseconds
    signal_GM(ii,:) = vfa_t1.analytical_solution(params);

    % CSF
    params.T1 = 4000;  % in milliseconds
    signal_CSF(ii,:) = vfa_t1.analytical_solution(params);
end

startup
clear all

%% Setup parameters
% All times are in milliseconds
% All flip angles are in degrees

% White matter
params.T1 = 900; % in milliseconds
params.T2 = 10000;
params.TR = 25;
params.TE = 5;
params.EXC_FA = 1:90;
Nex_range = 1:1:150;

%% Calculate signals
%
% To see all the options available, run `help vfa_t1.analytical_solution`

for ii = 1:length(Nex_range)
    params.Nex = Nex_range(ii);
    
    signal_analytical(ii,:) = vfa_t1.analytical_solution(params);

    [~, complex_signal] = vfa_t1.bloch_sim(params);
    signal_blochsim(ii,:) = abs(complex(complex_signal));
end

: (1) how many and which flip angles to use to acquire
data, and (2) correcting inaccurate flip angles due to transmit

value (i.e. single tissue) are the two flip angles that result in 71% of the maximum possible steady-state signal (i.e. at the

It has been well reported in recent years that the accuracy of
estimates is very sensitive to pulse sequence implementations
, and as such is less robust than the gold standard inversion recovery technique. In particular, the signal bias resulting from insufficient spoiling can result in inaccurate
estimates of up to 30% relative to inversion recovery estimated values
map accuracy and precision is also strongly dependent on the quality of the measured
, which can vary substantially between implementations
mapping pulse sequences are not as widely available as
, resulting in some groups attempting alternative ways of removing the bias from the
map through the use of image processing techniques
. The latter is not recommended, because most
scanners have default pulse sequences that, with careful protocol settings, can provide
maps of sufficient quality very rapidly
is still one of the most widely used

mapping methods in research. Its rapid acquisition time, rapid image processing time, and widespread availability makes it a great candidate for use in other quantitative imaging acquisition protocols like quantitative magnetization transfer imaging
maps are increasing in popularity, due to their growing availability on clinical scanners, rapid scan times, and fast post-processing computation time, thus making quantitative
mapping accessible for clinical applications. Generally speaking, dictionary-based quantitative

techniques use numerical dictionaries—databases of pre-calculated signal values simulated for a wide range of tissue and protocol combinations—during the image reconstruction or post-processing stages. Popular examples of dictionary-based techniques that have been applied to
, and Magnetization Prepared 2 Rapid Acquisition Gradient Echoes (MP2RAGE)
. Dictionary-based techniques can usually be classified into one of two categories: techniques that use information redundancy from parametric data to assist in accelerated imaging (e.g. CS,
F), or those that use dictionaries to estimate quantitative maps using the
images after reconstruction. Because MP2RAGE is a technique implemented primarily for
mapping, and it is becoming increasingly available as a standard pulse sequence on many
systems, the remainder of this section will focus solely on this technique. However, many concepts discussed are shared by other dictionary-based techniques.
MP2RAGE is an extension of the conventional MPRAGE pulse sequence widely used in clinical studies
. A simplified version of the MP2RAGE pulse sequence is shown in
. MP2RAGE can be seen as a hybrid between the inversion recovery and
pulse sequences: a 180° inversion pulse is used to prepare the magnetization for
sensitivity at the beginning of each
, and then two images are acquired at different inversion times using gradient recalled echo (
) imaging blocks with low flip angles and short repetition times (
imaging block, each excitation pulse is followed by a constant in-plane (“y”) phase encode weighting (varied for each
), but with different 3D (“z”) phase encoding gradients (varied at each
). The center of k-space for the 3D phase encoding direction is acquired at the
imaging block. The main motivation for developing the MP2RAGE pulse sequence was to provide a metric similar to MPRAGE, but with self-bias correction of the static (
) magnetic fields, and a first order correction of the transmit magnetic field (
). However, because two images at different
s are acquired (unlike MPRAGE, which only acquires data at a single
values can also be inferred, thus making it possible to generate quantitative

children.alt: Simplified diagram of an MP2RAGE pulse sequence. TR: repetition time between successive gradient echo readouts, TRMP2RAGE: repetition time between successive adiabatic 180° inversion pulses, TI1 and TI2: inversion times, \theta_{1} and \theta_{2}: excitation flip angles. The imaging readout events occur within each TR using a constant in-plane phase encode (“y”) gradient set for each TRMP2RAGE, but varying 3D phase encode (“z”) gradients between each successive TR.

Prior to considering the full signal equations, we will first introduce the equation for the MP2RAGE parameter (
) that is calculated in addition to the
map. For complex data (magnitude and phase, or real and imaginary), the MP2RAGE signal (
) is calculated from the images acquired at two

children.label: mp2rageEq1
children.html: SMP2RAGE=real(SGRETI1∗SGRETI2∗∣SGRETI1∣2+∣SGRETI2∣2)S_{\text{MP2RAGE}}=\text{real}\left( \frac{S_{\text{GRE}_{\text{TI}_{1}}}^{\ast}S_{\text{GRE}_{\text{TI}_{2}}}^{\ast}}{\left| S_{\text{GRE}_{\text{TI}_{1}}} \right|^{2}+ \left| S_{\text{GRE}_{\text{TI}_{2}}} \right|^{2}} \right)SMP2RAGE​=real(∣∣​SGRETI1​​​∣∣​2+∣∣​SGRETI2​​​∣∣​2SGRETI1​​∗​SGRETI2​​∗​​)

children.value: This value is bounded between [-0.5, 0.5], and helps reduce some
inhomogeneity effects using the phase data. For real data, or magnitude data with polarity restoration, this metric is instead calculated as:

children.label: mp2rageEq2
children.html: SMP2RAGE=real(SGRETI1∗SGRETI2∗SGRETI12+SGRETI22)S_{\text{MP2RAGE}}=\text{real}\left( \frac{S_{\text{GRE}_{\text{TI}_{1}}}^{\ast}S_{\text{GRE}_{\text{TI}_{2}}}^{\ast}}{S_{\text{GRE}_{\text{TI}_{1}}}^{2}+ S_{\text{GRE}_{\text{TI}_{2}}}^{2}} \right)SMP2RAGE​=real(SGRETI1​​2​+SGRETI2​​2​SGRETI1​​∗​SGRETI2​​∗​​)

children.value: Because MP2RAGE is a hybrid of pulse sequences used for inversion recovery and
, the resulting signal equations are more complex. Typically, a steady state is not achieved during the short train of

imaging blocks, so the signal at the center of k-space for each readout (which defines the contrast weighting) will depend on the number of phase-encoding steps. For simplicity, the equations presented here assume that the 3D phase-encoding dimension is fully sampled (no partial Fourier or parallel imaging acceleration). For this case (see appendix of
for derivation details), the signal equations are:

children.label: mp2rageEq3
children.html: SGRETI1=B1−e−TE/T2∗M0sin(θ1)×[(−effmz,ssM0EA+(1−EA))(cos(θ1)ER)n/2−1+(1−ER)1−(cos(θ1)ER)n/2−11−cos(θ1)ER]\begin{split} S_{\text{GRE}_{\text{TI}_{1}}}=&B_{1}^{-}e^{-\text{TE}/T_{2}^{\ast }}M_{0}\text{sin}\left( \theta_{1} \right) \\ &\times \Bigg[ \left( \frac{-\text{eff}m_{z,ss}}{M_{0}}\text{EA}+\left( 1-\text{EA} \right) \right)\left( \text{cos}\left( \theta_{1} \right) \text{ER} \right)^{n/2-1}\\ &\quad\quad+\left( 1-\text{ER} \right) \frac{1-\left( \text{cos}\left( \theta_{1} \right)\text{ER} \right)^{n/2-1}}{1-\text{cos}\left( \theta_{1} \right)\text{ER}} \Bigg] \end{split}SGRETI1​​​=​B1−​e−TE/T2∗​M0​sin(θ1​)×[(M0​−effmz,ss​​EA+(1−EA))(cos(θ1​)ER)n/2−1+(1−ER)1−cos(θ1​)ER1−(cos(θ1​)ER)n/2−1​]​

children.label: mp2rageEq4
children.html: SGRETI2=B1−e−TE/T2∗M0sin(θ2)×[mz,ssM0EA+(1−EC)EC(cos(θ2)ER)n/2−(1−ER)(cos(θ2)ER)−n/2−11−cos(θ2)ER]\begin{split} S_{\text{GRE}_{\text{TI}_{2}}}=&B_{1}^{-}e^{-\text{TE}/T_{2}^{\ast }}M_{0}\text{sin}\left( \theta_{2} \right) \\ &\times \Bigg[\frac{ \frac{m_{z,ss}}{M_{0}}\text{EA}+\left( 1-\text{EC} \right)}{\text{EC}\left( \text{cos}\left( \theta_{2} \right)\text{ER} \right)^{n/2}}-\left( 1-\text{ER} \right)\frac{\left( \text{cos}\left( \theta_{2} \right)\text{ER} \right)^{-n/2}-1 }{1-\text{cos}\left( \theta_{2} \right)\text{ER} } \Bigg] \end{split}SGRETI2​​​=​B1−​e−TE/T2∗​M0​sin(θ2​)×[EC(cos(θ2​)ER)n/2M0​mz,ss​​EA+(1−EC)​−(1−ER)1−cos(θ2​)ER(cos(θ2​)ER)−n/2−1​]​

children.value: , can also be reduced by careful pulse sequence protocol design
Dictionary-based techniques such as MP2RAGE do not typically use conventional minimization algorithms (e.g.
to fit signal equations to observed data. Instead, the MP2RAGE technique uses pre-calculated signal values for a wide range of parameter values (e.g.
), and then interpolation is done within this dictionary of values to estimate the

value that matches the observed signal. This approach results in rapid post-processing times because the dictionaries can be simulated/generated prior to scanning and interpolating between these values is much faster than most fitting algorithms. This means that the quantitative image can be produced and displayed directly on the
scanner console rather than needing to be fitted offline.

maps by using a dictionary with only dimensions (

children.value: -sensitivity can be reduced substantially with careful MP2RAGE protocol optimization
as one of the dictionary dimensions [

Example MP2RAGE dataset of a healthy adult brain at 7T and
map. Inversion times used to acquire this magnitude image dataset were 800 ms and 2700 ms, the flip angles were 4° and 5° (respectively),
= 6.7 ms. The dataset and code that was used were shared open sourced by the authors of the original MP2RAGE paper
The MP2RAGE pulse sequence is increasingly being distributed by
vendors, thus typically a data fitting package is also available to reconstruct the
maps online. Alternatively, several open source packages to create
maps from MP2RAGE data are available online

, and for new users these are recommended—as opposed to programming one from scratch—as there are many potential pitfalls (e.g. adjusting the equations to handle partial Fourier or parallel imaging acceleration).
This widespread availability and its turnkey acquisition/fitting procedures are a main contributing factor to the growing interest for including quantitative
maps in clinical and neuroscience studies.
values measured using MP2RAGE showed  high levels of reproducibility for the brain in an inter- and intra-site study at eight sites (same
hardware/software and at 7 T) of two subjects
. Not only does MP2RAGE have one of the fastest acquisition and post-processing times among quantitative
mapping techniques, but it can accomplish this while acquiring very high resolution
maps (1 mm isotropic at 3T and submillimeter at 7T, both in under 10 min
), opening the doors to cortical studies which greatly benefit from the smaller voxel size

Despite these benefits, MP2RAGE and similar dictionary-based techniques have certain limitations that are important to consider before deciding to incorporate them in a study. Good reproducibility of the quantitative
map is dependent on using one pre-calculated dictionary. If two different dictionaries are used (e.g. cross-site with different
vendors), the differences in the dictionary interpolations will likely result in minor differences in
estimates for the same data. Also, although the
maps can be reduced with proper protocol optimization, it can be substantial enough that further correction using a measured
mapping brings an additional potential source of error, so carefully selecting a
mapping technique and accompanying post-processing method (e.g. filtering) should be done before integrating it in a
. Lastly, the MP2RAGE equations (and thus, dictionaries) assume monoexponential longitudinal relaxation, and this has been shown to result in suboptimal estimates of the long
component for a biexponential relaxation model
, an effect that becomes more important at higher fields.
